summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Struggling Cities
summary: See which U.S. cities are under the most strain according to selected 2012 measures of fiscal health.

headline: Photos: Red Sox Close In on Title
summary: The Boston Red Sox are one win away from a championship.

headline: Corporate Watch
summary: Corporate Watch

headline: Red Sox a Win Away From Series Title
summary: Plus, as the NBA season opens Tuesday, a handful of loaded teams are taking aim at the Miami Heat. A few others, meanwhile, would like to turn the calendar to 2014 already.

headline: More Attention Urged for an Often-Unrecognized Disease
summary: Kidney disease, with a $41 billion annual Medicare tab for treatment, is fast becoming one of the costliest health threats in the U.S.

headline: SK Hynix Third-Quarter Profit Rises Sharply
summary: The memory-chip maker benefitted from strong chip prices and surging demand to report a net profit of $903 million.

headline: De Blasio Attracts More Big Donors
summary: The Democratic nominee for New York City mayor who has pledged to reduce the gap between the rich and poor, has collected more than 40% of his campaign contributions from big-ticket donors.

headline: Real-Estate Prices Begin to Firm Up in Areas Hit by Flooding
summary: Almost a year after superstorm Sandy, a study shows the prices and number of sales for homes in New York City's most flood-prone neighborhoods have stabilized and even begun to strengthen.

headline: Road-Weary Rangers Finally Get to Garden
summary: The Rangers played their first game Monday at the transformed Madison Square Garden, hoping to transform themselves into a winning team before too long.

headline: Namibia Taps Its German Roots for Oktoberfest
summary: The extent of Namibia's Germanic heritage is on display annually at this country's Oktoberfest. Namibia was a German colony for 35 years, around the turn of the 20th century, and things are still Teutonic here.

headline: NBA Season Preview: Nets Are Built to Contend. Are They Built to Last?
summary: The Nets added Kevin Garnett, Paul Pierce, Andrei Kirilenko and other bold-face names during the off-season. Is it enough for an NBA title? Here's a look at the 2013-14 Nets, who tip off their season Wednesday in Cleveland.

headline: Aiming for an Artistic 'Icon'
summary: Developer Stephen Ross has selected the British artist and designer Thomas Heatherwick to create what could be one of the most expensive works of public art in the world in Hudson Yards.

headline: A Week of Tricks and Treats
summary: Halloween may come only once a year, but with some planning, it can last more than just one night.

headline: Changing Lives With Donations, Eggs and Letters
summary: Mitzi Perdue, the socialite widow of Frank Perdue recently donated $25,000 to Catholic Big Sisters and Big Brothers of New York. She also writes letters to soldiers and decorates eggs for auction.

headline: Fashion's New Horizons
summary: Pratt Institute on Tuesday is announcing an initiative offering low-cost studio space, mentoring and production facilities to 30 design businesses, dubbed the Brooklyn Fashion and Design Accelerator.

headline: 'Shark Tank' Is a Boon For Mobile Breathalyzer
summary: Watching the TV show "Shark Tank" might help you avoid the drunk tank.

headline: Penn State Settles With Sandusky Victims
summary: Penn State will pay 26 sex-abuse victims of former assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky a total of $59.7 million in settlements, the school announced Monday.

headline: Photos: Singapore Biennale 2013
summary: Southeast Asia's diverse art scene is on show at the Singapore Biennale, which includes works by 82 artists and art collectives chosen by 27 curators. Take a tour.

headline: Christie: Win Would Set Example for GOP
summary: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie said Monday his election next week would send a message about what Republicans can achieve with a grass-roots approach to recruiting supporters.

headline: Ticket to the Universe
summary: A new show at the Hayden Planetarium narrated by Neil deGrasse Tyson, the planetarium's director, uses state-of-the-art science and computer technology.

headline: Woodbury Common Spruces Up for Shoppers
summary: Woodbury Common Premium Outlets, the sprawling 150-acre shopping mecca that is the country's largest outlet center, is getting a partial makeover.

headline: Snakes, Shellfish Traps Add to Mining Hazards
summary: The reappearance of a vast lake on the doorstep of one of Barrick Gold's biggest mines in Australia is causing unusual problems.

headline: With More Run and Less Pass, the Giants Go Old-School
summary: Eli Manning and the Giants' offense have ditched their trademark deep-passing attack for the sort of conservative, ball-control approach that dominated the NFL in the 1960s. It seems to be working.

headline: A Chamber Music Society Gets New Summer Home
summary: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will soon be summering upstate as a result of an agreement with the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

headline: Senate to Review All U.S. Spying
summary: Sen. Dianne Feinstein also said she expected that the White House would end all spying on leaders of allied countries. The moves follow revelations the U.S. has been spying on world leaders such as Germany's Angela Merkel.

headline: Hillary Will Run
summary: OUTSIDE THE BOX  By Pete du Pont  How could she not?

headline: Rio Tinto Makes Hay From a Water Obstacle
summary: Rio Tinto thinks growing hay might be the answer to disposing of huge amounts of water from beneath one of its big iron-ore mines in Australia, possibly clearing the way for it to bring up ore from below the water table.

headline: Deadly Storms Batter Mainland Europe
summary: Authorities across Western Europe began a giant cleanup operation Monday after one of the biggest storms in a decade pummeled first England and Wales and later parts of the Continent, killing at least 10 people and causing widespread travel chaos and power outages.

headline: Gold Fades From Investment Picture
summary: Central banks in Russia and elsewhere are cutting purchases of gold, further weighing on prices of the metal. Prices are down 19% year to date.

headline: Birds, Bees and Spies
summary: Europe's outrage over NSA spying ignores its own history and practice.

headline: Residents Weigh Post-Sandy Buyouts
summary: Thousands of people whose homes were destroyed by Sandy are considering abandoning the New York and New Jersey waterfront, with entire neighborhoods set to vanish.

headline: Apple Shows Its Mettle Ahead of Holidays
summary: Apple reported a third consecutive quarter of declining profits, but showed signs that both prices and profit margins are stabilizing despite heightened competition for its iPhone and iPad.

headline: Los Angeles Schools Leadership Questioned
summary: The Los Angeles Unified School District is slated to meet Tuesday to discuss whether to renew its superintendent's contract—a decision that could change the leadership of the nation's second-largest school system.

headline: U.K. Considers Islamic Bond Sale
summary: The issue, which could raise around $320 million, could come as early as next year, according to a statement from the prime minister's office.

headline: Electricity Use Impedes Aereo's March
summary: TV streaming service Aereo has more to worry about than broadcasters' lawsuits. Its system gobbles up electricity on the company's side of the operation.

headline: For Allentown, a Focus on Property Values
summary: Allentown once had a manufacturing base in textiles, heavy machinery and steel fabrication. But today many factories sit empty, and depressed property values are proving a major drag on the city's finances.

headline: Weak Tax Base Hurts Cities' Renewal
summary: Like hundreds of cities, Allentown, Pa., has struggled as people and businesses flocked to the suburbs, depressing property values. Now it is pinning its hopes on a $1 billion complex that includes a hockey arena and hotel.

headline: Rubio Backs Off His Immigration Bill
summary: The Florida Republican, who did more than any senator to rally conservative support for the sweeping immigration bill the Senate passed in June, now says his body should support whatever House Republicans can pass.

headline: Pediatricians Set Limits on Screen Time
summary: Parents should ban electronic media during mealtimes and after bedtime as part of a comprehensive "family media use plan," according to new recommendations from the American Academy of Pediatrics.

headline: She's Expecting, but When?
summary: A new home test tells a pregnant woman how far along she is in three minutes. But the test differs with most doctors' estimates on when to start counting the weeks.

headline: Syria Weapons Inspections Hit Snag
summary: The international agency overseeing the destruction of Syria's chemical weapons said Monday security concerns have prevented its inspectors from reaching the last two of 23 declared sites.

headline: Spying Revelations Add Hurdle to U.S.-EU Trade Talks
summary: Former officials and trade experts expressed concern that rising European distrust of Washington over U.S. spying could derail negotiations over a trade agreement with the European Union.

headline: Mexican Cartel Retaliates Against Civilians
summary: Crime groups launched coordinated attacks on a regional electricity grid that left hundreds of thousands of people without electricity and several dead in a rare case of civilians being deliberately targeted in Mexico's drug war.

headline: Unemployed Jersey Boys
summary: A ballot measure would increase the number of poor and jobless.

headline: India's Farmers Start to Mechanize
summary: Indian farmers switch to machines amid a shortage of labor, increasing productivity.

headline: Calcium Does a Hot-Dog Eater Good
summary: Adding a small amount of calcium carbonate to hot dogs may be an effective way to make processed meats safer to eat and reduce risks of a type of cancer, suggests a study.

headline: Health Site Recovers From Latest Snafu
summary: The troubled federal health-insurance website was recovering Monday after another outage, this time caused by a network failure at one of the companies supporting the site.

headline: Democrats Renew Push to Confirm Housing-Agency Pick
summary: The Obama administration is making a renewed push for Senate confirmation of Rep. Mel Watt (D., N.C.), to head a top housing-finance regulatory post and a vote could happen as soon as Thursday.

headline: Doing the Sugar Math for Halloween
summary: Research explains kids' cravings but fails to find evidence that candy causes "sugar highs" or can lead to sugar addiction. Parents increasingly use buybacks and tricks to limit the treats.

headline: Governor Testifies on Detroit Bankruptcy
summary: Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder testified in Detroit's bankruptcy case that a federal judge should decide whether to cut pensions promised to city workers.

headline: Spending on Tuberculosis Slips
summary: Few diseases need new medicines as much as tuberculosis, with most patients treated with drugs more than 40 years old. Yet global investment in new tools declined last year, a new report found.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Walter Russell Mead on how Jerusalem, Moscow, Beijing, Tehran and Riyadh are reacting to the White House's push for a nuclear deal with Iran.

headline: John Taylor: Economic Failure Causes Political Polarization
summary: Americans worried about sluggish growth and high unemployment are not extremists.

headline: Churchill Is Home Again and Here to Stay
summary: As Congress honors Britain's leader, you have to wonder what he'd make of today's isolationists and leakers.

headline: Germany Hasn't Earned Its Spying Outrage
summary: Funny that the chancellor of the world's third-largest arms-dealing country has rejected hard power.

headline: The Zen of Motocross
summary: Some people do yoga or play golf to de-stress, but Boland Jones prefers to take the edge off on his off-road motorcycle. The 53-year-old founder and CEO of a telecommunications provider rides motocross.

headline: Morgan Stanley Eyes More Buybacks
summary: After buying back its own shares from investors this year for the first time since the financial crisis in 2008, Morgan Stanley is considering asking the Federal Reserve for permission to purchase more stock next year.

headline: How Men, Women Run Marathons
summary: In a marathon field where everyone tried their hardest, finish times would be spread out evenly. Male finishers tended to bunch around whole-number times. Women were likelier than men to achieve negative splits.

headline: Your Money's No Good Here, Mr. Kim
summary: The U.S. antiterror arsenal includes Predator drones, Tomahawk missiles and men in gray suits who target rogue regimes' finances. Stewart Baker reviews Juan C. Zarate's "Treasury's War."

headline: Argentine Vote Lifts Hope for New Pro-Business Regime
summary: Argentina's congressional elections bolstered investors' hopes that an administration that seeks to improve the country's investment climate will succeed President Cristina Kirchner's populist government in 2015.

headline: Smartphones to Monitor Insulin and Smell Flowers
summary: The wireless industry will be transformed by 2023—if it can overcome a lack of spectrum.

headline: Who Really Employs Minimum-Wage Workers?
summary: Don't be fooled by organized labor's talking points. Small businesses do the hiring.

headline: Stephens: The Unbearable Lightness of Obama
summary: The president didn't know the NSA was spying on world leaders, but he's found time for at least 146 rounds of golf.

headline: Push to Screen Baby Boomers for Hepatitis C
summary: Millions of healthy adults from their late 40s to late 60s may get a surprising request at future doctor visits: Get tested for hepatitis C, the potentially fatal liver virus.

headline: Fund Seeks Overlooked Tech Gems
summary: T. Rowe Price fund manager Henry Ellenbogen has made a career of discovering and investing in startup technology companies, but lately he is focusing on new areas.

headline: From Underground to Mainstream
summary: Lou Reed's influence is so fundamental that it's impossible to imagine contemporary rock without him.

headline: Editors' Phone-Hacking Trial Opens
summary: Former senior News Corp editors Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson arrived at court Monday for the opening of their criminal trial, facing charges stemming from a probe into the alleged illegal interception of voice mails.

headline: The Legal Tab
summary: Large banks have agreed to more than $66 billion in settlements in recent years over credit crisis-related cases. See a timeline of the cases.

headline: Abortion Law Partly Blocked
summary: A federal judge blocked part of a Texas abortion law that gained national attention this summer after a lengthy filibuster by Democratic state Sen. Wendy Davis.

headline: Bourne Bites Into 'Beauty'
summary: "Matthew Bourne's Sleeping Beauty: A Gothic Romance," now at City Center, is a prime example of the imagination and originality that have marked the British choreographer's work since 1987.

headline: An Adolescent Adventurer in the Museum
summary: In his first major museum exhibition in the U.S. in 25 years and his first ever in New York, Chris Burden brings his Huck Finn-noir attitude to the New Museum.

headline: U.S. Banks' Legal Tab Is Rising
summary: U.S. banks have agreed to billions of dollars in mortgage-related settlements stemming from the financial crisis, but new estimates show the total figure could still rise sharply—to $107 billion or more—in coming years.

headline: Sandy - Then and Now
summary: In the year since superstorm Sandy struck on Oct. 29, 2012, rebuilding efforts have been ongoing along the East Coast. Images captured immediately after the storm and more recently illustrate its strength and the devastation it left behind.

headline: Fed Is House Bound
summary: Add worrisome pending home-sales data to the list of reasons why the Federal Reserve is likely to taper later rather than sooner.

headline: Copper Firm Ends Bid to Halt ETFs by J.P. Morgan, BlackRock
summary: Copper-wire maker Southwire has withdrawn its lawsuits fighting the launch of two exchange-traded funds, saying J.P. Morgan and BlackRock would be unlikely to launch the funds as originally outlined amid a retreat by banks from the physical-commodities business.

headline: Martha Stewart's New CEO Hails From Metals Industry
summary: Martha Stewart Living named director Daniel Dienst, a metals-recycling and turnaround executive, as its new CEO. The search took 10 months.

headline: Goldman Seeks to Better Work Conditions
summary: Goldman Sachs said it has spent the past year working to improve the work-life balance of most-junior employees, known on Wall Street as analysts, by reducing their hours and other measures.

headline: AMC's Premium Travel Show
summary: Buying Chelloherd could help AMC keep growing by selling stories of drug dealers and zombies to foreign audiences—but the price is high.

headline: Manchester City Finds Woe on Road
summary: Goalkeeper errors, defensive instability hurting Premier League's most expensively assembled squad away from home.

headline: Strong Euro Hits Luxury-Goods Sector
summary: The euro's strength against the U.S. dollar and the Japanese yen is estimated to dent the industry's world-wide growth by four percentage points this year, according to a Bain & Co. report.

headline: Oil Futures Rise on Libyan Production Fears
summary: A rally in Brent crude futures lifted U.S. oil prices to their highest level in a week, after reports of plunging Libyan production sparked concerns about supply disruptions.

headline: Seagate Reports Lower Earnings
summary: Seagate Technology said its fiscal first-quarter earnings fell 26%, pressured by sliding revenue at the data-storage company.

headline: Boeing Considers Nonunion Plant for 777X
summary: Boeing is evaluating whether to give its nonunionized South Carolina facility a bigger role in building the planned new version of its 777 long-range jet.

headline: Chinese Investors Move to U.S. Projects
summary: An unlikely participant increasingly is showing up in the bidding for distressed office buildings, hotels and other overleveraged commercial properties left over from the boom years: Chinese investors.

headline: Platini Calls for Expanded World Cup
summary: UEFA head wants a 40-team final in 2018, up from 32  sides next year; no replay in "phantom goal" game.

headline: Photos of the Day: Oct. 28
summary: In today's photos, a man tries to right a tree knocked down by strong winds in Germany, a tourist feeds gulls in China, astronauts attend preflight training in Kazakhstan, and more.

headline: Petrobras Surges on Pricing Proposal
summary: The Brazilian state-run oil company's shares jumped after it proposed a new fuel-pricing mechanism aimed at reducing government interference.

headline: Another High for S&P 500
summary: The S&P 500 index reached another record high, as investors took in stride disappointing results from blue-chip drug maker Merck and mixed economic data.

headline: Treasurys Weak After Sale
summary: Treasurys weakened despite a two-year note auction that drew the highest demand in a year, as investors were torn by mixed messages on the U.S. economy.

headline: Natural Gas Drops Nearly 4%
summary: Natural-gas futures fell nearly 4%, the biggest one-day drop in four months, as forecasts for warmer early November temperatures signaled a weak start to the winter heating season.

headline: Cantor's Betting Unit Eyed in Probe
summary: Authorities are investigating the sports-betting affiliate of bond firm Cantor Fitzgerald in connection with alleged money laundering of illegal gambling proceeds, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Capital Journal: Research Cuts Ought to Worry Business
summary: Automatic spending cuts are affecting the kind of basic research that has been worth billions to U.S. businesses over the decades, Gerald F. Seib writes.

headline: Germany Warns of Repercussions from U.S. Spying
summary: The German interior minister promised to investigate and prosecute alleged illegal activity, saying convictions could lead to expulsions.

headline: Ex-Lawmaker Sentenced to Three Years for Fraud
summary: A federal judge in Tucson, Ariz., sentenced former congressman Richard Renzi to three years in prison after a jury convicted him of 17 felony counts, including involvement in a fraudulent land deal.

headline: John Vinocur: Germany Hasn't Earned Its Spying Outrage
summary: It's far easier for Chancellor Merkel to feel put upon by America than to accept the responsibilities of global leadership.

headline: Dollar Bounces Back From Losses
summary: The dollar rose against major currencies, rebounding after its 1.4% drop over the past two weeks.

headline: Lions Turn Over a New Leaf in Win Over Cowboys
summary: The NFL's usually reliable turnover-differential statistic proved no match for Calvin Johnson and the Lions in Detroit on Sunday. They lost the turnover battle 4-0 but won the game anyway.

headline: J.P. Morgan Names Boardman as CEO of Wealth Management Unit
summary: Michael Boardman, who has a 25-year career in wealth management, joins J.P. Morgan from U.S. Bancorp, where he was president of that firm's private client reserve business.

headline: Plots & Ploys: The San Francisco Feat
summary: Less than three years ago, Veritas Investments Inc. bet big on a portfolio of more than 70 troubled San Francisco apartment buildings once owned by the Lembi family. It appears that the company's investment was money well spent.

headline: Flying on a Wing and a Beer
summary: One look at its results will tell you that Buffalo Wild Wings has hit on a simple but effective formula for attracting and keeping customers. It boils down to: "Wings. Beer. Sports."

headline: Consumer Choice and Ethanol in Motor Fuel
summary: Did Sen. Chuck Grassley mean it when he said: "We want to be sure that small-business owners are able to provide the gasoline blends that their customers want"? Most customers want ethanol-free gasoline but can't get it because of people like Sen. Grassley.

headline: Hooray for Well-Rounded Students
summary: Regarding M.N. Stabler's "The College Admissions Passion Play" (op-ed, Oct. 19): Ms. Stabler's stress is shared by thousands, but why? Singular passion isn't listed as an application requirement at any college.

headline: Throwing Sacrifices Away in Iraq
summary: My son was one of the 4,488 patriotic Americans killed fighting in Iraq. He gave his life for a cause in which he believed. I and many other Gold Star Parents are hurt that our politicians decided to just let Iraq go down the toilet after all the sacrifices made by so many.

headline: ACA Didn't Start Medical Crisis but May Help End It
summary: Concierge medicine, the high price of medical school diverting young people to other careers, the movement of physicians away from private practice to more salaried, hospital-based business models—none of this is the product of the ACA.

headline: The Sunshine of Disclosure and Some Intimidation, Too
summary: The growing acceptance of corporate political disclosure by leading American businesses speaks for itself. Companies understand that secret political spending is fraught with risk.

headline: Vivendi to Buy Rest of Canal Plus
summary: Vivendi agreed to pay close to $1.4 billion to buy the 20% it doesn't already own of pay-TV channel Canal Plus. Lagardère had been looking to sell the stake for a higher price.

headline: Camry Loses Key Endorsement
summary: Consumer Reports magazine has dropped its recommendation of the Toyota Camry, a perennial favorite among sedans, after a poor showing on a new crash test.

headline: Congolese Soldiers Flush Rebels From Stronghold
summary: Congolese soldiers pushed rebels out of a stronghold and into the hills along the Rwandan border on Monday, an offensive that army leaders hope will quell the latest unrest in the African country.

headline: Clemson: A Football School, With a Team to Match
summary: The Journal visited Clemson before the Tigers' showdown against Florida State.

headline: After Complaints, AT&T Delays Fee Changes
summary: Sprint Corp. is among customers objecting to loss of discounts for special access lines, saying the move is anticompetitive and complaining to the FCC.

headline: Alrosa Still Needs Buffing
summary: Diamonds are a commodity where demand is expected to outstrip supply. But Russian diamond miner Alrosa, whose share sale has increased its free float to 23%, still has some cleaning up to do.

headline: GM Lifts Opel Marketing in Russia
summary: General Motors is raising the Russia profile of its German-built Opel brand vehicles even as the U.S. auto maker pursues a strategy of making Chevrolet its predominate nameplate globally.

headline: European Stocks Slide On Thin Trade
summary: Inclement weather and caution, ahead of important U.S. data releases later this week, kept London quiet; elsewhere in Europe school holidays kept traders and investors away from their desks.

headline: High Crime Rate in Peru Hurts President
summary: A growing sense of insecurity has helped bring Ollanta Humala's popularity to the lowest level since he took office in mid-2011.

headline: Merck Profit Falls on Lower Sales
summary: Merck's earnings fell 35% on disappointing sales of its blockbuster diabetes drugs and signaled that it would consider shedding certain products and businesses.

headline: Trying to Get Someone to Hate You
summary: The Northwestern Wildcats want to call it a big rivalry, but the Iowa Hawkeyes don't. They face each other Saturday in Iowa City, but have little shared history.

headline: Banks Seek an Allowance on Pay
summary: In response to the EU's planned bonus cap, banks are considering paying more in 'allowances' that are defined as neither salary nor as a variable bonus.

headline: Draghi Risks Having Worst of All Worlds
summary: Agenda: The odds are stacked against ECB President Mario Draghi in his effort to conduct a broad assessment of the euro zone's biggest banks.

headline: Thai Ex-Premier Charged With Murder
summary: Former Prime Minister Abhisit Vejjajiva and his deputy were charged with murder in connection with a 2010 crackdown on protesters, potentially helping the ruling Puea Thai party force through a controversial amnesty bill.

headline: Vietnam Airlines, GE Sign $1.7 Billion Deal
summary: Vietnam Airlines signs a $1.7 billion contract to buy and lease 40 new jet engines from a unit of General Electric, as it seeks to raise its profile.

headline: Pending Home Sales Show Sharp Drop
summary: Higher mortgage rates and rising home prices scared off prospective home buyers in September, sparking the fourth straight monthly drop in a key measure of home sales.

headline: Mongolia Leader on Four-Day Visit to North Korea
summary: Mongolia's president arrived in Pyongyang with the goal of nudging North Korean leader Kim Jong Un toward peace and denuclearization, but observers say Pyongyang is unlikely to embrace Mongolia's model of transformation.

headline: Icahn Likes North Dakota for Shareholders, but State Fails to Draw Public Companies
summary: Carl Icahn recently pointed to North Dakota as a model of corporate governance. But only two public companies are incorporated in the state, and one of them is controlled by Mr. Icahn.

headline: Indian Blasts Fuel Political Tensions
summary: India's main opposition party blamed the government Monday for what it called "grave security lapses" after several explosions shook a rally for the party's polarizing prime-ministerial candidate.

headline: Google Amends EU Antitrust Proposals
summary: Google offered new proposals to address EU concerns that the company unfairly uses its search engine to promote its own services.

headline: KKR to Invest in Indian Hospital Operator
summary: U.S. private-equity firm KKR will invest about $90 million in Indian hospital operator Apollo Hospitals Enterprise as demand for health care increases in the nation of more than 1.2 billion people.

headline: Trial of 3 Activists Tests China Waters
summary: Three New Citizens Movement activists of went on trial in a case rights advocates see as a test of how hard a line Chinese authorities plan to take with the group.

headline: George Magnus: Prospects for Reform at China's Plenum
summary: Beijing's economic reforms will not be so radical as to jeopardize the status quo.

headline: Hedge Funds Warm to China
summary: More foreign hedge funds are devoting resources to China, attracted by strong returns, the potential of a nascent local industry and signs that the country will continue to develop its financial markets.

headline: Brazil's Sugar Exports Slow After Port Fire
summary: Sugar exports from Brazil's busiest port have slowed since a massive fire earlier this month destroyed the country's biggest sugar terminal.

headline: India's Central Bank Predicts Stubborn Inflation
summary: India's central bank said it expects inflation would remain outside its comfort zone this fiscal year, amid expectations that controlling prices would remain the prime focus when the central bank reviews monetary policy.

headline: Deere to Sell Majority Stake in Landscapes Business
summary: Deere & Co. agreed to sell a majority stake in its Landscaping business to Clayton, Dubilier & Rice LLC for about $300 million.

headline: Valuing Twitter v. Facebook
summary: Based on IPO price versus pre-IPO price, Twitter is taking a more conservative approach to pricing than Facebook did. But by some measures, Twitter appears more expensive than Facebook stock is right now.

headline: U.S. Industrial Production Up 0.6%
summary: U.S. industrial output improved in September after a surge in the volatile utility segment helped bolster weaker gains in manufacturing, returning to the 2007 average for the first time since the recession.

headline: Straits Trading Buys Stake in ARA Asset
summary: The Singaporean resources and property firm is buying a fifth of a real-estate fund manager backed by Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing, as part of the companies' investment tie-up.

headline: Maruti Profit Jumps Threefold
summary: Maruti Suzuki reported a nearly threefold increase in quarterly net profit and expressed confidence that it can outperform the Indian car market in sales growth this financial year.

headline: Battling Wildfires in the U.S.
summary: The western U.S. dealt with several major wildfires this year. See photos from some of the affected areas.

headline: China Think Tank Offers Reform Wish List
summary: A top policy-advisory group is about to unveil proposals for reforming China's economy—including less coddling of state enterprises and giving farmers the right to sell their land for the first time.

headline: Biogen Posts Higher Earnings, Outlook
summary: Biogen's third-quarter earnings climbed 22% as sales for its multiple sclerosis treatment Tecfidera boosted the biotech's revenue.

headline: Powerful Storm Disrupts U.K. Travel
summary: Commuters in the southern U.K. woke up to travel chaos, with rail, flight and ferry services suspended and roads leading into London littered with debris, as a heavy storm battered England and Wales.

headline: More Than 100 Killed as Rains Hit Eastern India
summary: More than 100 people have been killed and hundreds of thousands rendered homeless as heavy rains pounded eastern India, causing floods and hampering relief work in areas that were ravaged by a massive cyclone two weeks ago.

headline: Getting Back on Track After Sandy
summary: Although much has been accomplished, the region's transit workers are still hauling away or repairing equipment ruined by the storm, and making do in some facilities that were hastily or partly repaired.

headline: Voices: Kevin Kneafsey, on the Value Risk Parity Offers Clients
summary: "What risk parity allows us to do is balance risk much more equally than we could in a traditional portfolio. And by balance risk, I don't mean across asset classes, which is probably the most common misconception about the strategy. We're talking about balance across the key forces that drive all asset returns; things like economic growth risk, interest rate risk, and inflation risk."

headline: U.K. Charities Turn to Bond Market
summary: At a time when the U.K. government is cutting spending, charities and other community organizations are finding bonds an attractive way to raise large sums of cash quickly.

headline: China's Suning Invests in Video Site
summary: China's Suning Commerce will team with Hony Capital to invest $420 million in video site PPTV as the electronics retailer grapples with China's shift to online sales.

headline: Russia Cuts Gold Holdings, Central Banks Remain Net Buyers
summary: Russia cut its gold holdings for the first time in a year in September, although the world's central banks remained net buyers of gold last month, according to data from the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Hard Facts for Zoomlion
summary: The Chinese construction-equipment maker is still digging out of a hole, even with a critic pushed aside.

headline: Burger King's Profit Soars on Decrease in Costs
summary: Burger King's third-quarter earnings soared as the fast-food chain posted significantly fewer operating expenses and as same-store sales increased in its international regions.
